segment.source: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic (Windows 10)
segment.target: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic (Windows 10)

segment.source: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic
segment.target: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic

segment.source: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic
segment.target: Protect Devices from Unwanted Network Traffic

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: Although network perimeter firewalls provide important protection to network resources from external threats, there are network threats that a perimeter firewall cannot protect against.
segment.target: Although network perimeter firewalls provide important protection to network resources from external threats, there are network threats that a perimeter firewall cannot protect against.

segment.source: Some attacks might successfully penetrate the perimeter firewall, and at that point what can stop it?
segment.target: Some attacks might successfully penetrate the perimeter firewall, and at that point what can stop it?

segment.source: Other attacks might originate from inside the network, such as malware that is brought in on portable media and run on a trusted device.
segment.target: Other attacks might originate from inside the network, such as malware that is brought in on portable media and run on a trusted device.

segment.source: Portable device are often taken outside the network and connected directly to the Internet, without adequate protection between the device and security threats.
segment.target: Portable device are often taken outside the network and connected directly to the Internet, without adequate protection between the device and security threats.

segment.source: Reports of targeted attacks against organizations, governments, and individuals have become more widespread in recent years.
segment.target: Reports of targeted attacks against organizations, governments, and individuals have become more widespread in recent years.

segment.source: For a general overview of these threats, also known as advanced persistent threats (APT), see the Microsoft Security Intelligence Report.
segment.target: For a general overview of these threats, also known as advanced persistent threats (APT), see the Microsoft Security Intelligence Report.

segment.source: Running a host-based firewall on every device that your organization manages is an important layer in a "defense-in-depth" security strategy.
segment.target: Running a host-based firewall on every device that your organization manages is an important layer in a "defense-in-depth" security strategy.

segment.source: A host-based firewall can help protect against attacks that originate from inside the network and also provide additional protection against attacks from outside the network that manage to penetrate the perimeter firewall.
segment.target: A host-based firewall can help protect against attacks that originate from inside the network and also provide additional protection against attacks from outside the network that manage to penetrate the perimeter firewall.

segment.source: It also travels with a portable device to provide protection when it is away from the organization's network.
segment.target: It also travels with a portable device to provide protection when it is away from the organization's network.

segment.source: A host-based firewall helps secure a device by dropping all network traffic that does not match the administrator-designed rule set for permitted network traffic.
segment.target: A host-based firewall helps secure a device by dropping all network traffic that does not match the administrator-designed rule set for permitted network traffic.

segment.source: This design, which corresponds to Basic Firewall Policy Design, provides the following benefits:
segment.target: This design, which corresponds to Basic Firewall Policy Design, provides the following benefits:

segment.source: Network traffic that is a reply to a request from the local device is permitted into the device from the network.
segment.target: Network traffic that is a reply to a request from the local device is permitted into the device from the network.

segment.source: Network traffic that is unsolicited, but that matches a rule for allowed network traffic, is permitted into the device from the network.
segment.target: Network traffic that is unsolicited, but that matches a rule for allowed network traffic, is permitted into the device from the network.

segment.source: For example, Woodgrove Bank wants a device that is running SQL Server to be able to receive the SQL queries sent to it by client devices.
segment.target: For example, Woodgrove Bank wants a device that is running SQL Server to be able to receive the SQL queries sent to it by client devices.

segment.source: The firewall policy deployed to the device that is running SQL Server includes firewall rules that specifically allow inbound network traffic for the SQL Server program.
segment.target: The firewall policy deployed to the device that is running SQL Server includes firewall rules that specifically allow inbound network traffic for the SQL Server program.

segment.source: Outbound network traffic that is not specifically blocked is allowed on the network.
segment.target: Outbound network traffic that is not specifically blocked is allowed on the network.

segment.source: For example, Woodgrove Bank has a corporate policy that prohibits the use of certain peer-to-peer file sharing programs.
segment.target: For example, Woodgrove Bank has a corporate policy that prohibits the use of certain peer-to-peer file sharing programs.

segment.source: The firewall policy deployed to the computers on the network includes firewall rules that block both inbound and outbound network traffic for the prohibited programs.
segment.target: The firewall policy deployed to the computers on the network includes firewall rules that block both inbound and outbound network traffic for the prohibited programs.

segment.source: All other outbound traffic is permitted.
segment.target: All other outbound traffic is permitted.

segment.source: The following component is recommended for this deployment goal:
segment.target: The following component is recommended for this deployment goal:

segment.source: Active Directory: Active Directory supports centralized management of connection security rules by configuring the rules in one or more Group Policy objects (GPOs) that can be automatically applied to all relevant computers in the domain.
segment.target: Active Directory: Active Directory supports centralized management of connection security rules by configuring the rules in one or more Group Policy objects (GPOs) that can be automatically applied to all relevant computers in the domain.

segment.source: Other means of deploying a firewall policy are available, such as creating scripts that use the netsh command-line tool, and then running those scripts on each computer in the organization.
segment.target: Other means of deploying a firewall policy are available, such as creating scripts that use the netsh command-line tool, and then running those scripts on each computer in the organization.

segment.source: This guide uses Active Directory as a recommended means of deployment because of its ability to scale to very large organizations.
segment.target: This guide uses Active Directory as a recommended means of deployment because of its ability to scale to very large organizations.

source.pc: Restrict Access to Only Trusted Devices

target.pc: Restrict Access to Only Trusted Devices
